summary: This is a court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the defense's motion to exclude the government's expert witness, Dr. Lisa Rocchio, in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The court largely denies the motion, allowing Dr. Rocchio to testify about grooming, trauma, and victim behavior in child sexual abuse cases, but excludes one specific opinion about 'grooming-by-proxy'.

events.title: Daubert Hearing
events.description: Court conducted a hearing on the admissibility of expert testimony from Dr. Lisa Rocchio, where both parties examined her.

events.title: Court Issues Opinion on Expert Testimony
events.description: Judge Nathan issued this written opinion, largely denying the defense's motion to exclude Dr. Rocchio's testimony but excluding one specific opinion.

locations: Alpert Medical School of Brown University
keyFacts: The court ruled that Dr. Lisa Rocchio, an expert on child sexual abuse trauma and grooming, is qualified and her proposed testimony is largely admissible under the Daubert standard.
The court excluded one specific opinion: that the presence of a third party can facilitate grooming ('grooming-by-proxy'), finding it lacked sufficient support in the relevant literature.

Dr. Rocchio's admissible opinions include: perpetrators use grooming/manipulation; grooming can prevent minors from understanding/disclosing abuse; abuse causes long-term trauma; and nondisclosure/delayed memory are common among victims.

The defense argued Rocchio's methods were unreliable due to lack of error rates and reliance on patient reports, but the court found these objections misplaced in the field of clinical psychology studying sexual abuse.
The opinion cites numerous prior cases from multiple circuits where similar expert testimony on grooming and trauma in sexual abuse cases has been admitted.
